questions.question_text: Which action FortiGate performs on traffic that is subject to a per-IP traffic shaper of 10 Mbps?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C refer to SD-WAN_6.4_Study_Guide page 117

choices.B: FortiGate applies traffic shaping to the original traffic direction only.
choices.C: FortiGate limits each source IP address to a maximum bandwidth of 10 Mbps.
choices.D: FortiGate guarantees a minimum of 10 Mbps of bandwidth to each source IP address.
choices.A: FortiGate shares 10 Mbps of bandwidth equally among all source IP addresses.

questions.question_text: Which behavior reflects how BGP tags work with SD-WAN rules?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C refer to SD-WAN_6.4_Study_Guide page 226

choices.B: Routes tags are mapped to the local preference attribute.
choices.C: Route tags can be used to specify the destination subnets in SD-WAN rules.
choices.D: If the destination network learned using BGP tag changes, you must re-configure the BGP tag so the information on the SD-WAN rule is updated.
choices.A: SD-WAN rules that use BGP tags have precedence over regular policy routes.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
By enabling preserve-session-route, the FortiGate marks existing session routing information as persistent. Therefore, routing look-up only occurs on new sessions.

https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.4.5/administration-guide/139692/routing-concepts

I think A can't be right as the FG must always do a route lookup for a new session, not only after a route change but as soon as the session is created.
D seems stupid, leaving BC.

Selected Answer: AB
AB refer to SD-WAN_6.4_Study_Guide page 67

147 / 5.000
Resultados de traducci√≥n
a) correct
B) sessions are marked as route_preserve, not persistent
C) this alternative is confusing
Does anyone know the correct answers?
can some please confirm the answer?

comments.content: My ERROR!! It is not AB but BC rather

choices.A: FortiGate performs routing lookups for new sessions only after a route change.
choices.B: FortiGate marks the routing information on existing sessions as persistent.
choices.D: FortiGate always blocks all traffic after a route change.
choices.C: FortiGate flushes all routing information from the session table after a route change.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D refer to SD-WAN_6.4_Study_Guide page 120

Selected Answer: D
ans is D
I think correct answer is D

choices.A: Create a new firewall policy, and the select the SD-WAN zone as Incoming Interface.
choices.C: In the firewall policy, select Proxy-based as Inspection Mode.
choices.B: In the traffic shaping policy, select Assign Shaping Class ID as Action.
choices.D: In the traffic shaping policy, enable Reverse shaper, and then select the traffic shaper to use.
The ISDB contains the IP addresses and port ranges of well-known destinations.
choices.A: The ISDB is dynamically updated and reduces administrative overhead.
choices.B: The ISDB applies rules to traffic from specific sources, based on application type.
choices.C: The ISDB requires application control to maintain signatures and perform load-balancing.
